title: Thursday, 19th April, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hello, hi, good morning. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's thing

OnYourRight Morning all
AAAA Bonjour les amis ! Le soleil est là !
Soundbuy Morgen.......
BE11:03am

Quite a lot going on, though that's usually the case on a Thursday.

Paper Chase Hullo
TKZ Hi there...
BE11:04am

Where to start? I guess we can preempt the inevitable comments from the same old people and mention ....

11:04 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,813, up 59 (+1.57%), High: 3,825, Low: 3,736, Volume: 1.10m
BE11:04am

So ................ Up again.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
A. M. Morning one and all.
TKZ any thoughts on yesterday VIX spike? How was it done?
Soundbuy Three days left?
BE11:05am

The mood music around Shire right now is to expect an update pretty soon.

A. M. The parsing of the musk missive was a fun read.
11:05 am
BE11:06am

That's slightly stating the obvious, since Takeda has until April 25 under the PUSU.

BornCynic Good morning - I have learnt something new today. That there are wolves on Instagram:https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/apr/19/wolves-of-instagram-jordan-belmont-social-media-traders
BE11:06am

More interestingly, there seems to be a fair bit of noise around right now regarding prices.

Grouchmonkey Morning
The Eye anyone for £RTHM, the share so many love to hate..a turnaround or a dead cat bounce?
Soundbuy Take that it includes the 25th then........
BE11:07am

We at the FT, and I'm sure all of our peers, have been chasing a quite strong rumour that Takeda's offered ballpark £46.50 per share in cash and equity.

A. M. @BornCynic: fakery? on instagram? I'm shocked, etc.
Soundbuy Notice Shire's Q1 earnings due on the 26th......day after then
pancakes or waffles @A.M. agreed. VCF (voting camel formation) was also a great one
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Which'd be a big premium even on yesterday's price. 20%+. The idea is that the offer went in over the past 48 hours or so.

pancakes or waffles *vomiting
BE11:09am

TO BE CLEAR -- we've checked this out with people familiar with the companies and, if we could report with certainty, we would.

BE11:09am

But we can't. So it's RAW.

A. M. @pancakes -- I guess TA is a PETA-compliant form of haruspicy.
11:10 am
BE11:10am

£46.50 would be a premium of more than 20 per cent against yesterday's close, so pretty punchy. And as per my understanding of the Panel rules, Shire wouldn't have to say anything whatsoever during the process.

BE11:10am

Let me cut to some sellside to say, "Takeda's quite wee".

BE11:10am

Here's Barclays.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

The summary is that whilst a specific offer may indeed emerge next week, if it does it is likely to involve a large paper element given the improbability of Takeda raising the equivalent of greater than its own market cap in credit and /or equity financing for an outright takeover. Thus even if this came at a suitably attractive price point (which we believe would be challenging given the foregoing and recent decline in Takeda’s share price), this will likely further complicate the path to potential consummation given likely limited appeal for many investors in holding combined Takeda/Shire equity (even if they were permitted to from a geographic mandate perspective). From a standalone perspective we continue to see challenges for Shire ahead of clarity on the full HAVEN3 data at WFH in May in particular:

GBKrona @BE - Takeda offer would have to be at least £20 cash of £46-47 otherwise it will effectively be a reverse takeover?
BE11:12am

"[W]hilst a sizeable subgroup of Shire investors would be happy to crystallise an exit opportunity within a reasonable valuation range, we also continue to believe the offer would need to be meaningfully in excess of £40/sh to stand a reasonable chance of success," says Barclays.

BE11:14am

Talks a little about an "obvious financing challenge" for Takeda, though also notes that it has some interesting options for funding, as per this Reuters story: https://www.reuter...SBRE98O1BJ20130926

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Taking into consideration Takeda’s modest degree of current leverage ($6bn or 1.8x trailing EBITDA) that clearly creates obstacles to Takeda assembling an attractive offer (i.e. at a sufficient valuation point and with a sufficient cash component). That said, we do, however, note that the advisers appointed by Takeda (i.e. Evercore and specifically Francois Maisonrouge) were also participants on the Shire side during the 2014 Abbvie defence. We also note that Takeda may have some unorthodox (from a Western perspective) credit financing options available given the historical involvement of entities such as the DBJ in foreign acquisitions

J L Hello All
BE11:15am

Barclays also unconvinced on strategic rationale.

BE11:15am

Market seems more convinced though, I note. Up 3.6% live.

chopper bear any comment on Saga sorry been away a few days couldn't see any in last few ML
Pharma Got to love "[W]hilst a sizeable subgroup of Shire investors would be happy to crystallise an exit opportunity within a reasonable valuation range".Translation. Many shareholders will sell if the price is high enough.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

Which puts a certain amount of pressure on Shire to make a statement, of course.

AAAA reuters : TAKEDA 4502.T MAKES INDICATIVE TAKEOVER PROPOSAL TO SHIRE SHP.L WORTH ABOUT 46.50 POUNDS A SHARE - SOURCES - Reuters News
AAAA now this on reuters
BE11:21am

....

Paper Chase I'm now fully expecting a Unilever moment, with statement appearing at 11:59am
BE11:21am

..............

11:21 am
BE11:21am

...........................................

BE11:22am

Okay, Reuters has this on the tape to "sources"

VV75 well there has to be an announcement now for sure
BE11:22am

And, yes, £46.50.

Paper Chase Aw I was wrong
VV75 I think they are quoting you BE
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Unlucky, Reuters! Nearly had the scoop! Ah well!

Groundhog Day Well played @BE ;-). Are you a Reuters Source now? :D
chopper bear still trading 39 lp
undefined
AAAA well played BE ! u're the boss !
VV75 not on BB yet, so still some movement possible after they quote the "news"
BE11:24am

Okay, let's push on with the other stuff.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

("(Bloomberg) -- FT Alphaville chatroom says the Financial Times has been chasing a "quite strong rumour" that Takeda offered ballpark GBP46.50 per share in cash and equity for Shire.")

AAAA *TAKEDA IS SAID TO MAKE TAKEOVER PROPOSAL FOR SHIRE: REUTERS
BE11:24am

("chatroom" .... Embarassed smile )

VV75 ther it is
AAAA on BBG
Paper Chase Very well played indeed
DJ fantastic stuff
wayneJ This does therefore assume that UK investors want to hold Takeda paper?
Miss Piggy if not "chatroom" then what?
chopper bear pfizer counter ? lol
Forester Lets be honest, it is mostly a chatroom these days - I dont look at the ROTL
GBKrona @BE - very well flushed out!!
BE11:26am

Let's hoof some sellside up so I can take a moment and answer some of my emails.

DJ up 7% live now
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Let's go with Intu.

Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 192.55, down 7.35 (-3.68%), High: 192.65, Low: 189.65, Volume: 3.17m
wayneJ Would it be better to say 'Daily Market Pontifications by Pope Bryce are....'
Flaneur More of a 'snug', surely?
BE11:27am

Barclays not keen.

DRichi 'Discussion board' sounds a bit more professional I think
AAAA in red now
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Intu is left out in the cold: Intu shareholders are the clear losers in this situation in our opinion. Intu shares initially rallied after the Hammerson take-over announcement, only to drift down in the months that followed. After Hammerson’s decision to no longer recommend the takeover, Intu shares reverted to pre-bid levels. We see a challenging outlook for Intu on a standalone basis as a high LTV combined with toppy valuations and a benign retailer outlook will likely impose further challenges. We do not believe there are any other likely buyers for the portfolio out there.

AAAA for people with a color filter :)
wayneJ It took 2 minutes in intra-day tick data for the Bryce effect to impact SHP
Pharma They should have used the official tag-line. "Alphaville's daily thing with writing and stuff"
Tom Dalgleish Not a chatroom. More a benign dictatorship
Miss Piggy #NotAChatroom: how about "audienced feedbacked market commentary"?
BE11:29am

As for Hammerson .....

wayneJ Incidentally would Takeda have to have a shareholder vote? And is there any chance of another Japanese co. going hostile on Takeda.
cleverhedge nice one @BE
BE11:30am

A u-turn from the Hammerson board, but better late than never: The board has
some important questions to answer though. The Hammerson board concluded only
four months ago that it would be in the best interests of shareholders to merge with
Intu, only to decide now that Hammerson is able to drive better value on a standalone
basis. Given how little has changed in the underlying market on a company level and on
a share price level, we wonder how well the standalone scenario was considered and
investigated in the first place. Nonetheless, we agree that Hammerson is better off on a
standalone basis.

wayneJ My view is that Bloomberg ought to pay a license fee or only have a delayed feed on what Bryce says....
11:30 am
BE11:30am

(@Tom Dalgleish: I'm flattered that you consider me benign.)

Miss Piggy @wayneJ: fair usage though isn't it.
ftrada anything on essentra?
BE11:31am

.... which is a common theme among the sellside. Hammerson's moves over the past few months makes them look pretty damn silly.

Noddy Boffin @BE: re Tom Dalgleish, as a dictator you will have to get used to flattery.
Miss Piggy Incidentally investing.com has a chat sidebar on its S&500 Futures page.
wayneJ @Miss Piggy - I am not entirely convinced on that argument - a drop of nectar from Bryce is being relayed by a service that charges $24k per yr....
Maverick Bloomberg now quoting reuters on SHP
BE11:32am

Does that put Hammerson in play? Not for Klepierre in the short term, obviously, unless something friendly happens, but there are other property developers in the world.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Simon, for one.

VV75 anything on the SFO probe into Ultra Electronics?
Miss Piggy @waynej: I'm a big fan of Bloomberg, though I do not have a terminal. All those terminal fees cross subsidise tv and radio for small investors like me.
tangledodyssey Yes, Simon owns 20% of Klépierre
wayneJ Chair of Klepierre is 'David E Simon' - who also happens to be chair of Simon Property
Miss Piggy @waynej: just like drinking in a posh hotel's bar, the guests pay for the refurbishment.
BE11:34am

Jefferies' Mike Prew is very good. Here's his quarterly update thing.

BE11:34am

We have upgraded HMSO to HOLD (UNPF) as, having jilted intu at the altar, the HMSO boards position is now untenable and facing a Martin Sorrell day of reckoning. Intu is orphaned, over geared and over distributing with Peels Hldgs 27% stake potentially unstable.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Board is culpable of failing to engage with Klépierre after the bid approaches at 615p and then 635p with HMSO's 790p defense NAV valuation less reliable than the FY17 776p. There's a six month moratorium before Klepierre can re-bid and AXA buying 25% of Bluewater may be discounted which estate agents can't ignore. HMSO's views that the French retail market as 'fragile' and the slow down in designer outlet centre growth are concerning. HMSO management now risks under-delivering on its 6%-8% pa DPS growth having called off its merger with INTU on new found caution on the UK shopping centre market.

wayneJ Yep - I use Bloomberg but dollar for dollar Bryce (and the FT) are better value. [Senses he is going to get invited (again) for 're-education' by Bloomberg drones]
tangledodyssey It is Simon who wants to get into UK mkt since Unibail-Rodamco bought Westfield and he is falling behind
undefined
Fox SAGA
BE11:36am

Ultra Electronics mentioned ..... though we have very little clarity on what's happened here.

11:36 am
Ultra Electronics Holdings PLC (ULE:LSE): Last: 1,279, down 109 (-7.85%), High: 1,322, Low: 1,229, Volume: 520.78k
wayneJ David Simon has a $251M change in control payment via accelerated vesting of equity (I claim fair useage of Bloomberg's Bio function :-) )
tangledodyssey Simon could bid direct from USA?

The news on the tape is that Ultra's reported itself to the Serious Fraud Office re. suspected corruption in Algeria.

BornCynic @MIssPiggy - an internal auditor of a large hotel chain as one of his audit tests had to go to the hotel bar to buy a drink to make sure that he was given the correct change.He decided to quit the job when he realised that he was waking up in these hotels with no idea as to which country he was in..................
wayneJ I think there is a thorny tax / REIT issue - am thinking (but not looked in detail) that doing it via Klepierre helps
BE11:37am

Too soon to estimate the impact.

Miss Piggy @BornCynic: I would not quit that job.
11:38 am
BE11:38am

The folk to feel sorry for here are Berenberg, incidentally, who upgraded Ultra on Friday.

AAAA https://www.standard.co.uk/business/barclays-raider-s-radical-plan-to-shake-up-jes-staley-s-banking-empire-revealed-a3818161.html
BornCynic @MissPiggy - business travel sounds good until you have had to suffer it................
BE11:39am

Ultra has weathered a difficult few months following the November 2017 profit warning, departure of the CEO, and termination of the planned acquisition of Sparton (its US sonobuoy joint venture partner). We believe the market has now digested these latest developments and priced in Ultra’s inherent risks, as evidenced by the c25% sell-off in the share price since October. In our view, the sell case has largely played out, and based on improving fundamentals we now view downside risk as limited.

BE11:39am

Turns out downside is limited unless the SFO gets involved. Black swans and all that.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

No more prescient comment to hand, though Goldman does have a holder note out saying:

wayneJ Shire is coming off - anyone want to work out the half life of a FT AV BE comment? Is it an exponential function?
BE11:40am

We are Neutral rated on Ultra Electronics. To reach our 12 month price target of 1,323p we apply 11.5x EV/DACF to our 2019 forecasts (our target multiple assumes a 1:1 relationship between EV/GCI and CROCI/WACC) and discount back 1 year. Upside/downside risks to our view and price target include: (1) further budget pressure in the UK; (2) an extended Continuing Resolution in the US; (3) large-scale M&A; and (4) large FX moves.

Tom Dalgleish Here all the swans are black
BE11:40am

Beyond that, you're on your own.

tangledodyssey Hammerson culd still do a "friendly" deal with Klépierre even without waiting thew six months if shareholders lean on Hammerson mgt
Tom Dalgleish So a white swan event is where the majority are wrong
11:41 am
undefined
chopper bear @wayne i imagine a statement will follow by noon
wayneJ I assume no one has read the Nikkei Asian Review article saying that a bid for Shire depends on the agreement of the Takeda board (dated 13 April)

Quick stopover at WPP?

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,168, up 51.5 (+4.61%), High: 1,169, Low: 1,136, Volume: 2.59m

AAAA yep, massive mine i guess on barc
wayneJ And 'Weber does not appear to have even broached the topic with the board. "Nothing's been talked about within the company," one senior Takeda official said. The president may have a particularly hard time convincing the drugmaker's external directors, who occupy eight of the 13 board seats, that the acquisition's financial risk is worth the potential payoff. '
BE11:44am

It gives me an excuse to link to this very long and elegant New Yorker thing, though.

wayneJ Source - https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Business-Deals/A-Takeda-bid-for-Shire-hinges-on-outside-directors-nod
11:44 am
BE11:45am

On April 14th, the W.P.P. board announced that, after thirty-three years as C.E.O., Sorrell had resigned, after an outside law firm hired by the board investigated his alleged “personal misconduct.” Sorrell vehemently denied the allegation. We don’t know for certain the cause; the board and Sorrell agreed to sign, in the words of someone close to the board, “strict N.D.A.s,” meaning that they would not share the results of the investigation. This lack of transparency has provoked a hurricane of rumors among W.P.P. executives and the advertising community.

BE11:45am

https://www.newyor...pps-martin-sorrell

cleverhedge @BE check that new BARC plan
BornCynic Non disclosure agreements / gagging agreements should be made illegal.
BE11:46am

.... "a hurricane of rumors among W.P.P. executives and the advertising community" that doesn't seem to have reached print, weirdly. Unless I'm missing something, the Yorker story doesn't even nod in the vague direction of what type of scuttlebutt it is.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

.......... which is weird.

wayneJ Also worth reading - https://www.ft.com/content/c0f53462-c638-11e4-9bf4-00144feab7de - especially 'A group of dissident shareholders wrote to the board complaining bitterly that Takeda had been hijacked by foreign interests.' ---- bet those shareholders will be delighted by another foreign acquisition after Nycomed.....
TKZ Sorrell is a pretty straight sort of fellow. No one reported seeing him in Clapham.
BE11:48am

Anyway, as to Publicis -- great March. Q1 organic growth about a percentage point ahead of consensus. Why? Dunno. No idea. Facebook fallout, maybe?

BE11:48am

Here's Kepler.

GBKrona John Wayne very quick on the draw today! :-)
BornCynic Time to enjoy this good weather - thanks BE / ROTR
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Most pleasing was a continued improvement of North America, its biggest region (55% of net sales), which grew by 2.8% organically (KECH: 1.5%; consensus: 2.2%), above that achieved by Omnicom (-0.1%), driven by McDonalds, Lionsgate, Molson Coors and Southwest Airline wins and marking the fourth consecutive quarter of positive growth after a lean spell.

Miss Piggy anyone bothered by retail sales collapse or do we just chalk it up to "beast from the east"
BE11:49am

Europe (30% of net sales) also managed to return to positive growth after two quarters of declines (0.3% vs. 0% KECH, -1.5% consensus) despite a tough comp (5.5%), helped by decent performances in the two largest territories, France (+2.3%) and the UK (+1.3%), which together account for half of this region’s activity, offsetting weakness in Germany (-4.1%) and Italy (-9.7%) off tough comps. Asia-PAC (10% of net sales) was the only disappointment, -4.6% organically, versus our +0.5% and consensus -1.1%, due to a -11.6% decline in Australia on the discontinuation of the Quantas call centre contract, which sounds like it could have been below-average margins. LatAm (3-4% of net sales) was up 11.5% organically (vs. +2.5% KECH, +2.4% consensus) thanks to the Petrobras and Bradesco wins, while Middle East and Africa (2-3% of net sales) was up +4.8% (vs. 2% KECH, 2.1% consensus)

BE11:50am

And Citi.

cracklenpop @TKZ WPP sponsored the notorious President's Club gig - until they didn't.
11:50 am
BE11:50am

After all the concern about 1Q organic growth sparked by the group’s comments about January/February at the CMD in March, it turns out the group is in fine fettle – 1.6% organic growth is materially ahead of expectations. Historically, swings of just 30-50bps have resulted in significant moves in the share price on the day of results, so if history is a guide this should be taken very well. The key thing, though, is not the quarter but the continued steady improvement in growth trend which should give comfort that the perceived ‘structural’ challenges faced by the group (and the industry as a whole) are not as severe as perhaps the market fears. With scope for upgrades/rerating through the year, we are bullish and rate PUB Buy.

wayneJ @GBK - :-) Golden rule - when looking at the dynamics of Japanese companies - read the Nikkei - not scuttlebutt from arbs in Mayfair who reverse broke their story.....
hornblower anything on Debs
BE11:52am

(@cracklenpop: there's an interesting story attached to that. Sadly, it's not for airing here though.)

undefined

Should we do a twofur on retail and Debs?

jaws anything in AVV on today's news ?
cracklenpop @BE may explain why the timing of the board's move agin him?
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 23.00, down 0.32 (-1.37%), High: 23.82, Low: 20.36, Volume: 13.85m
VV75 please
VV75 thank you

Profit down 50% or so, which is what operational gearing does for you on the way down.

red DEB death by a thousand cuts as there continue to be folks that havent yet worked it out it seems

CFO exits, having tired of adding negative numbers to negative numbers.

BE11:55am

Dividend halved to fund another recovery strategy, which seems no more developed than its previous dozen recovery strategies.

11:55 am

Big idea this time is to improve the offer and customer experience

wayneJ DEB need to work out what they offer to who and why?
Threadneedle How long before CEO time to jump ship from Deadenhams?
red @wayneJthere is a mkt for that lot but is it commercially viable for debenhams is the q
Mr Diamond @BE. I see AIQ no longer suspended
Tom Dalgleish It's a "who am I?" moment like the English cricket team had 30 years ago
TKZ There are some heavy bets on continued 2-10 spread flattening. If this continues today with increase at the back end, we'll see good sell-off. volume has been abysmal for all indices.
BE11:58am

Faster supply chain, better sourcing, refresh the Designers catalogue (because everyone's now realised, I guess, that it's the same damn cardigan irrespective of whether it's branded John Rocha, Jasper Conran or Butterfly by Matthew Williamson).

Flaneur @Miss piggy - Retail is 'because internet' and the potholes because Putin hacked all the road surfacing machines. All else is 'because Trump'.(being Irish this is only half-funny; everything - and I do mean everything from bad roads to duff comb-overs - was blamed on the Brits undermining us. To see this happening in the UK merely reflects the gangster-ish half-wittery with which and by whom we are being governed)
BE11:59am

Here's Peel Hunt.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The average lease length is 18 years, leaving
little opportunity for major change. That said, 25 stores are up for lease renewal in the next five years and Debenhams are engaged with landlords try to right-size the store footprint where possible. The new store format trials will be extended to three stores this season and 15-20 more by Christmas. We can’t fault the strategy, the race is on to create a relevant offer for customers by peak.

red @TKZwhile inflation benign i guess so. u need hint of inflation to stretch the long end. certainly the 10 is dead in water whilst inside 2.60/2.95.
BE12:00pm

They see full-year going to £50m from £55m

wayneJ I have pontificated on these pages before on M&S; DEB is the same as M&S minus the flair, heritage or reputation.
BE12:00pm

Debenhams is delivering cost savings to create
a more appropriate cost base for the business. The group’s problems have clearly been exacerbated by cost inflation, NLW and fx pressure, but the heart of the issue remains the product offering and store environment, both of which have become tired. Recovery is far from certain and we would rather focus on structural growth stocks or market leaders with strong balance sheets, such as DFS, which offers exposure to consumer recovery at an attractive valuation, without the fear of failure.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And, from Investec, a brave call from Kate Calvert.

BE12:01pm

We cut FY18/FY19e PBT by 11%/9% respectively. However, the 50% DPS cut should enable management to address historic infrastructure under-investment quicker. While DEB remains structurally challenged, we believe better stock management and increasing concession income should drive a profit rebound in FY19e. Upgrade to BUY.

TKZ @red Inflation is coming. Gas here in the US is approaching $3. And metal prices? IMF is a good indicator of market direction. when was it that Lagarde said global economy in full swing? Now we are seeing weakness across the board except some patches in the US.
BE12:01pm

Hope vs experience.

Blank canvas Another good session. Many thanks to all
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Albeit with the addition of a balance sheet that doesn't look stressed -- yet.

BE12:02pm

While Debenhams is structurally challenged, the balance sheet is solid in our view. We welcome the dividend cut which will enable management to address historic infrastructure under-investment more quickly. With a profit rebound expected in FY19e from better stock management and increasing concession income within the sales mix, we think the valuation has become too cheap given our perception of the potential for corporate activity. Our TP, based on a 30% discount to average NTM PE since IPO, falls to 25p from 28p reflecting the downgrade, but with a forecast total return of 27% following this morning’s share price fall, we upgrade to Buy (from Hold).

red @ TKZyes i think you should see it soon. i was expecting it at the start of the year, but prices dipped and inflation followed. still crude is well into its reverse shs pattern with a tgt near 80 bucks, you would think getting there drags inflation higher by year end.
TKZ Talking of metal prices. Again russian sanction is one stupid thing. Chinese are given the chance to empty their Al inventory and more increase supply down the line.
wayneJ BE - does that change when companies have to put leases on balance sheet? (Re stressed balance sheet)
Miss Piggy 2s10s is flattening but rates are up, need to do a correlation analysis on yield curve twist viz-a-viz yield curve raise
BE12:03pm

As for retail sales: -1.2% month-on-month (m/m) in March

red pretty sour considering easter earlier than last year.
Pseudonym @TKZ Cor $3/litre is steep...
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Fuel sales particularly weak, which is a fairly good indicator that it's snow rather than trend.

red so pmis bad, cpi lower than forecast, wages softer than f/c, sales down. but they will still raise rates in may ???

Maverick SHP 40 handle
BE12:05pm

Therefore, still on for a rate hike in May. Probably.

TKZ @Pseudonym, not yet there. But we are approaching. Gas price here varies from towns to towns sometimes quite a lot.
red about 70% rpiced in
BE12:05pm

When did we last quote Howard Archer? Let's quote him now.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

“Retail sales volumes slumped 1.2% m/m in March and were up just 1.1% year-on-year (y/y) as the recent severe weather, particularly at the beginning of the month, took a major toll on activity. This outweighed some help to retail sales in March coming from the earlier Easter this year.

“The underlying retail sales performance had already been weak in the early months of 2018 as consumer spending power remained limited. While retail sales volumes rose 0.8% m/m in February, this had a lacklustre rebound after sales had only been flat in January after falling in December (by 1.3% month-on-month).

“Retail sales volumes fell 0.5% q/q in the first quarter of 2018. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) indicated that this is likely to knock 0.03 percentage point off first quarter GDP growth.

“This fuels suspicion that GDP growth slowed to no more than 0.3% q/q in the first quarter, and could very well have been as soft as 0.2% q/q.

“There was a particularly sharp drop in fuel sales in March as the severe weather conditions deterred some people from driving. Non-food sales fell 0.6% m/m in March, as did food sales. Department store sales were the only sector to see monthly growth in March as online sales were boosted by offers for Mothering Sunday and Easter.

“Some welcome news for consumers came from annual shop price inflation dropping to a 14-month low of 1.9% in March, down from 2.5% in February and a peak of 3.3% in September 2017.”

Outlook for Consumer Spending

“The squeeze on consumers is now clearly waning with inflation moderating and earnings growth firming. Indeed, real income growth has just returned to positive territory - albeit marginal – after being negative since the early months of 2017.

“Specifically, consumer price inflation has fallen back to a 12-month low of 2.5% in March from a peak of 3.1% last November. We expect inflation to trend down further to be back to 2% by the end of 2018.

“Meanwhile, earnings growth has been trending gradually up recently, and this seems likely to continue as a consequence of recruitment difficulties in some sectors and higher inflation fuelling some increased pay awards. Specifically, the latest data shows that regular earnings growth climbed to a two-and-a-half year high of 2.8% in the three months to February. Meanwhile, total weekly earnings growth remained at 2.8% in the three months to February, the highest rate since September 2015.

“Further good news for consumers saw employment rise by 55,000 in the three months to February to reach a new record high of 32.262 million. However, it is questionable whether employment can sustain healthy growth going forward given the tightness of the labour market.

“There are factors that look likely to limit the upside for consumer spending. Consumers are likely to face higher interest rates as we expect the Bank of England to tighten monetary policy by 25 basis points in May and would not rule out a similar hike in November.

“This may well encourage consumers to look to rebuild their balance sheets and be cautious over their spending and borrowing - given the extended squeeze on their purchasing power and the fact that the savings ratio fell to a record low of 4.9% in 2017.”
